We interpret the MPC’s shorter targeting horizon as a period of
two years rather than three. The conditioning path underlying the November 2017 Inflation Report assumed a cumulative 60bp tightening of monetary policy over three years. On the MPC’s forecasts, that rate path implied a 15bp inflation overshoot three years ahead. The conditioning path underlying the February 2018 Inflation Report assumes a cumulative 70bp tightening of monetary policy over three years. On the MPC’s forecasts, that rate path would imply a 16bp inflation overshoot two years ahead, and an 11bp inflation overshoot three years ahead.

A. M. @Mouselet: morning. is that a response to the chinese racing pigeons story?

BE11:12am

First, we interpret the MPC’s shorter targeting horizon as a period of two years rather than three. Second, we think the magnitude of the MPC’s expected two-year-ahead inflation overshoot (which matches the overshoot implied by our own CPI forecast) implies that policy will be tightened sooner than our base case assumption. Third, we interpret the MPC’s reiteration of a “limited” and “gradual” path of prospective policy tightening as indicative of little change in the Committee’s overall view of the appropriate level of interest rates in the longer term. We therefore add an extra 25bp interest rate rise — in May — to our existing forecast of a 25bp increase in November. Beyond 2018, our forecast is unchanged: we expect one 25bp increase in 2019 and one 25bp increase in 2020.

Based on occurrences in the supply side of the economy, such as soaring labor shortages, the BoE may be underestimating emerging price pressures. Still, the Bank may also be under-estimating the impact that its unconventional policies could have. These policy cross-currents likely explain why the BoE remained keen to stress that any further rises in bank rate would be applied at a gradual pace and limited extent, and why its policy projection was revised just 0.1 percentage point higher. Taking into account all the factors we have discussed, we still expect the BoE to hike again this year, but in H2, probably August.

On a day when the BoE delivers most of what we need to convince the market of a hike in May the question we face now is how far can the move can go? Over the last year market moves have been swift in reaction to BoE comments and/or Brexit developments, but slow to follow through. The difference this time is that the BoE has been more aggressive than even we were expecting. It’s no longer about the timing of the first or indeed the following hike (with not much after that), but about the level of the terminal rate and how quickly we get there. By shifting its policy focus away from the 3yr to the 2yr part the BoE will be even more sensitive to prevailing developments in the data.
Our base case is that we see two hikes a year for the next two years. While that is our base case, if the current pace of the global expansion continues we would not put it past the market’s ability to look at the possibility of more than two hikes per year if inflation continues to overshoot the BoE’s forecasts.
There are also downside risks to the data. Before now the market had been hesitant to change its opinion on the MPC’s reaction function. It is pretty clear that the lamda argument has now shifted. Instead, the underlying fundamentals that feed into it are the potential pitfalls to watch out for. PMIs have fallen, but so has the BoE’s assumption of trend growth potential already, so unless we see a further aggressive decline more hikes
should be our base case. But if next week's CPI inflation release disappoints we think it will be pivotal as to how aggressive the market prices this cycle. The BoE expects CPI inflation to hold firm at 3.0% y-o-y, but we and the market expect it to be lower at 2.9%. Those are the short-term macro risks, but of course there is the politics.

BE11:20am

If the idea of a transitional deal agreed by March is thrown out, that could reverse most of GBP’s gains to date. This is a low risk because it is the government’s stated aim with the backing of the cabinet. Then there is the constant risk of a change in leader or indeed an election/second referendum called. But these are tail risks and have been overly focused on in the past and wrong footed those that have been short GBP. It’s something we expect could rear its ugly head in the aftermath of Theresa May’s next speech. But without a date set for that it is something we shall revisit in due course. As BoE Governor Mark Carney said "Brexit has not yet happened", so it can't be the validation of each and every trade

wayneJ Daft question - falling rates lead to the NPV of a cashflow going up and therefore the value of housing for the same level of rent. However rising rates will mean the discount value of a rent stream goes down - which means a landlord (who borrows in nominal currency) is likely to want to force up rent to maintain the value of his property. So do rising rates force up rents as well?

latest-generation high-nickel-containing NMC grades. On the back of accelerated ramp-up of existing capacity
investments, Umicore expects to ship ~100k tons of cathode material sales in 2019. This compares to Umicore’s
capacity of ~15k tons at the end of 2015 per JPMe.

BE11:34am

Li-ion to remain dominant for the medium-term; capacity is key
Most experts agree that nickel-rich, high voltage Li-ion batteries will be the dominant technology for the automotive market medium-term, and see promising innovation driving further performance gains. But with demand for Li-ion cathode materials projected to grow at a 14% CAGR (2017-25), i.e. by ~600kt cumulative, limited visibility on supply is a rapidly growing concern in the industry.
Don’t forget the anode, electrolytes, separators, binders…
Battery optimisation is not all about the cathode. A number of presentations focused on sizeable performance improvements being delivered from elsewhere in the cell – silicon anodes for example are claimed to increase driving range by up to 30%. Solvay claims that its electrolyte technology helps batteries operate at higher voltages (up to 5.0v), while improving cycle life by c.4x compared to standard electrolytes. Most are confident these materials will be cost-effective ($/kWh basis).

BE11:35am

Raw material supply a big focus; highlighting the need for better recycling

Many presentations [ AABC Europe 2018, a trade conference focused on the latest in battery technologies] focused on the lack of visibility on raw materials. Consistent with our Metals team’s latest view in MINING: Usain Cobalt, most noted expectations of a shortage in Cobalt and Lithium around 2022e. This highlighted the need for greater investment in recycling, and for batteries made with more abundantly available materials (Al, Zn) – though this is many years out.
Umicore best exposed, though the fragmented market provides multiple opportunities As global leader in cathode materials and battery recycling, Umicore is best exposed within our Chemicals coverage. But we see good growth prospects for smaller/newer entrants too: BASF, JMAT should benefit from an undersupplied cathode market. Also, Solvay, Arkema (electrolytes /binders), Wacker Chemie (anodes) are well positioned to drive further Li-ion battery optimisation.

Woodward's business is approximately 75% Aerospace with 25% Industrial, split on an EBIT basis. The Aerospace business is comprised of 50% commercial aerospace with an equal split of OE and AM. The remainder of the business is split between military and business jets. WWD's largest customers include GE and BA, which accounted for 16% and 11% of revenues in 2017. Sales to BA were up from 8% in 2016. In addition to BA, UTX and Airbus are sizable customers for WWD, but account for less than 10% of revenues. Although some portion of airframe sales may be at risk, the systems business is largely sold to the engine OEMs and are also under long-term contracts. There are several reasons why the transaction makes sense in our view. First, BA is focused on lowering unit costs. There are three factors which drive unit cost including model mix, supply chain, and labor / productivity costs. Supply chain is the largest cost in our view and could account for 60-65% of the cost base. As such, the company has focused on supply chain costs through Partnering for Success initiatives as well as vertical integration. One example, is the company's JV with Adient. Given issues in the supply chain and relatively low barriers to entry, BA formed a JV with Adient to develop and manufacture economy class seats. In another step in July 2017, BA announced it would create its own in-house avionics unit with a start of 500 employees. Another area of interest for BA includes actuation. BA has operations at its Sheffield and Portland facilities to build actuation systems for 777s and 737s. WWD's operations would add scale with both actuation and airframe content across several platforms including the 747 (WWD's current content of $800K), 777X ($430K), 737MAX ($275K), and 787 ($230K) platforms. Another potential merit for the transaction could be WWD's new facilities. The company has invested greater than $500MM in three new facilities over the past several years. Two of the facilities are primarily dedicated to aerospace and focused on the company's ramp in its commercial aerospace business, which we forecast to grow at a 12% rate over the next few years. These facilities would support the narrowbody ramp but potentially the next middle market aircraft for BA.

red you can read about plenty of battery failures btw

BE11:47am

Taking our FY20 (Sept. year end) EBITDA estimate for WWD of
$485MM and recent blended transaction multiples of ~12.5X (vs. 10.5x our FY20 EBITDA), this would imply a transaction value of ~$6.1BB or ~$90/share. We would not view the Industrial business as a fit for BA given exposure to power generation, transportation, and oil & gas markets. The Industrial segment accounts for $725MM of revenues with ~15% EBITDA margins. We figure if a deal were to occur BA could divest this portion of the business. A sale of the business could generate proceeds in the range of $875MM.

BE11:57am

Umicore's expanded build-out of its cathode operations should lead to 175k tonnes of capacity by 2021. By comparison Johnson Matthey announced last September that it aims to produce only 10k tonnes by the same year, with additional production beyond that "based on demand". Should NMC prove to be the adopted technology (and we note, in any case, Umicore's flexible operating plants which would allow for different cathode materials) then this puts pressure on long-term market share models for JMAT (and others) given the possibility that this capital commitment by Umicore increases its chances of holding (or even gaining) its current leading global market share in the range of 20-25%.
